Byoung Sung Ahn a' * , Sang Cheol Lee b, Dong Ju Moon a, Byung Gwon Lee a ` CFC Alternatives Technology Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology. P.O.Box 131, Cheongryang, Seoul, South Korea Department of Chemical Engineering, Kunsan National University, Miryong Dong 68, Kusan, Chonhuk 573-360. City. South Korea Received 17 February 1995; accepted 3 August 1995 Abstract The hydrodechlorination reaction of dichlorodifluoromethane (CFZC12) has been studied under an atmospheric pressure at 130-210 over Pd/AIF3 catalyst. The effects of various reaction conditions on the catalyst performance in terms of the reaction rate and product distributions were extensively investigated and the adsorption behaviours of H2, CFzC12, CHFzCI, CHZFZ and CH3F on the catalyst surface are compared. In addition, the plausible reaction scheme has been proposed based on the experimental observations. Under the assumption that the formation of two main products, CHZFZ and CH, proceeds through the hydrogenation of intermediate species, CFz , , the reaction rate constants have been calculated by fitting the experimental data with the reaction rate expression. Keywords: Dichlorodifluoromethane; Hydrodechlorination reaction; Adsorption behaviour; Reaction scheme 1. Introduction Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) have been widely used as refrigerants, blowing agents, propellants or cleaning agents due to their outstanding properties such as stability, nontoxicity, nonflammablity, good thermodynamic properties and so on. However, production and use of CFCs are currently being phased out under international agreements, Montreal Protocol, because of global environmental concerns. Chlorine atoms dissociated from CFCs are believed Corresponding author. Tel. ( + 82-2)9585854, Fax. ( + 82285809. 1381-1169/96/$15.00 1996 Elsevier Science B.V. It would be particularly desirable if recovered CFCs can be converted to harmless and preferably to useful chemicals. Various technologies for treating CFCs before being released to air have been proposed in recent years. These technologies are mainly based on catalytic or non-catalytic decomposition processes. Catalytic decomposition technology includes oxidation [ 1,2], hydrolysis [3,4] and hydrogenation [5,6]. CFZC12 (CFC-12) may be catalytically transformed to CH 2 F2 (HFC-32) via hydrodechlorination. HFC-32 is thought to be one of the most promising candidates for 84 B.S. Ahn et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical 106 (1996) 83-91 replacing CHF2CI (HCFC-22) which has been mainly used as low-temperature refrigerants. The reaction of CF2Cl2 with hydrogen has been studied by Du Pont Inc. at 500-700 over Pt, Ag, Co and Cu catalysts [7]. The maximum selectivity to CHFC12 and C2F4 was found to be 39%. Aida et al. [3] compared the performance of Au/A1203 and Au/C0304 catalyst for the decomposition of CF2C12. Au/A1203 was found to have a higher activity than Au/C0304. They concluded that Au/C0304 had only a high oxidation activity, while Au/A120.had both oxidation and hydrolysis activity. Coq et al. [5] studied the hydrogenation of CF2C12 in the gas phase at atmospheric pressure over Pd black and Pd supported on alumina, graphite, or AIF3, and found the highest selectivity to CH2F2 over Pd/AIF, catalyst. In this work, extensive experimental investigations on the hydrodechlorination reaction of CF2C12 have been carried out under an atmospheric pressure at 130-210 over Pd/AIF~; catalyst. The plausible reaction scheme has been proposed based on the experimental results and adsorption characteristics. The reaction rate constants were calculated by fitting the experimental data with the reaction rate expression. 2. Experimental 2.1. Preparation and characterizations of Pd l A1F3 catalyst A catalyst containing 3.45 wt.% of Pd on AIF~, was prepared by the conventional impregnation of AIF~3 with aqueous PdCl2 solution. The necessary amount of PdC12 was dissolved in 20 cm 3 of 0.1 N HO solution, and then it was added to 5 g of AIF3. The solution was evaporated at about 60 in a rotary evaporator for several hours. After drying at 120 overnight, the impregnated catalyst was calcinated at 450 in the electric furnace for 2-3 h. Prior to the reaction, the calcinated catalyst was reduced in situ in a hydrogen stream. Adsorption The adsorption experiments of H2, CF2C12, CHF20, CH2172, and CH3F were conducted in a conventional volumetric apparatus as shown in Fig. 1. A rotary vacuum pump and a diffusion pump were used to connect with the volumetric apparatus, and the liquid nitrogen trap was installed between the apparatus and the pumps for the removal of vaporized silicon oil. The pressure change during the adsorption step was measured by a pressure gauge (MKS Instruments, USA). After 0.3 g of catalyst was charged to the volumetric apparatus, the volume of the apparatus was measured using He gas. The reduction of catalyst was performed under the hydrogen flow of 20 cm 3/min at 300 for 1 h. After the reduction, adsorbed hydrogen was discharged through a vacuum line for 1 h. Then the apparatus was cooled to 150 to perform hydrogen chemisorption experiment. 4 1 4 3 s s CATALYST 5 5_ 85 The hydrogen of high purity grade at a certain pressure was introduced into the adsorption apparatus and the equilibrium pressure was measured after 30 min. The adsorption equilibrium isotherm of hydrogen was determined from the adsorption amounts obtained for various pressures. The effluent from the reactor was bubbled through a scrubber with 0.1 N NaOH solution to remove any HCl and HF formed, and then the remaining moisture was removed through a CaC12 dryer. It was assumed in the first model that CF2C'2 was physically adsorbed to form CF2C12. Coq et al. [5] used a classical Langmuir-Hinshelwood model with competi tive adsorption of CF2Cl2 and H2 as a kinetic model, which involved this adsorption model. As indicated in Fig. 7, the second model was found to be much better than the first model in predicting the adsorption behaviour of CF2C12. Conclusion The major products of CF2CI2 hydrodechlo rination reaction was found to be CH2F2 and CH 4. The competitive behaviours between CF2Cl2 and H2 during the reaction was con firmed from the experimental results and ad sorption characteristics. In predicting the ad sorption behaviour of CF2C12 on Pd surface, the model for dissociative adsorption with the for mation of CF2C1 '" and CFZ , was found to be -j 1.0E-4 superior to the model for physical adsorption. The formation of the products could be ex plained by the direct hydrogenation of interme diate species, CF? , , rather than by the consecu tive scheme of CF2C12 _+ CHF2Cl --> CH2F2 -+ CH3 -4 CH4 A reaction scheme for the CF2C12 hydrodechlorination was proposed and the overall reaction rate expression derived from the scheme was confirmed experimentally to describe the reaction well. coredata.dc:description: The hydrodechlorination reaction of dichlorodifluoromethane (CF2Cl2) has been studied under an atmospheric pressure at 130–210°C over Pd AlF3 catalyst. The effects of various reaction conditions on the catalyst performance in terms of the reaction rate and product distributions were extensively investigated and the adsorption behaviours of H2, CF2Cl2, CHF2Cl, CH2F2 and CH3F on the catalyst surface are compared. In addition, the plausible reaction scheme has been proposed based on the experimental observations. Under the assumption that the formation of two main products, CH2F2 and CH4, proceeds through the hydrogenation of intermediate species, CF∗2∗, the reaction rate constants have been calculated by fitting the experimental data with the reaction rate expression.
